comments.author: MrM
comments.content: I'm a huge fan of Mexican, Italian, and Thai kitchens.  However, I've never had Indian food before, and I'm becoming more and more curious about it and willing to try it.  Does anyone share the love for these cuisines and if so, what similarities do they share with Indian?  Any commonalities I should look for in flavors or textures?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Of the three, I would say the most similar is Thai for the shared love of spices, but even then the flavor profiles and cooking methods are pretty different. My suggestion would be to go eat at an Indian restaurant (preferably a few times) and see how you like the flavors. This will give you a good sense of what you are aiming for if you decide you'd like to cook this cuisine at home. If you do decide to try, I think you will find it to be very interesting and rewarding.

comments.author: Sarah
comments.content: Thanks for this simple and delicious recipe. I bought a huge bunch of green fenugreek at Ramle Market and this is a great way to use it (I usually make Persian food with it). The soup is  simmering now in my kitchen :-)

comments.author: George Carey
comments.content:
Just finished making this and i's wonderful. I used jalapeños and fresh kasoori methi. The result is a beautiful looking dish with just enough warmth to bring out the flavors yet mild enough that I think my wife will even enjoy it.

I doubled the recipe and I'm so glad I did. Thank you!

comments.author: ILEANA
comments.content:
Hi:
I want to thank you for this wonderful ideas to cook healthier. I have a question, can I use the dried little pellets like fenugreek for this recipe? I'm not sure how to use this kind.
Thanks!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I think you would need to grind them, with a blade-type coffee grinder or mortar and pestle for example.

comments.author: ILEANA
comments.content: Well thank you so much! I will get started to using them ! Then I will also look into getting some of the fresh one. Great Blog !
